screening_results.reason: Although the study uses fMRI during a social task (Cyberball) with whole-brain analyses in an adult sample (mean age ~19.9) and reports relevant activation, it includes participants with a psychiatric diagnosis: 9 of 46 participants met criteria for social anxiety disorder (SAD) and were retained in analyses (social anxiety was a primary continuous predictor). The review exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders. Therefore the study does not meet the 'healthy participants' inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This study used functional MRI during a social interaction task (virtual ball-toss/Cyberball), satisfying the requirement for an fMRI social-related task. Participants were healthy adults (final analyzed N=31; mean age ≈21 years), within the 18–60 range. Analyses were whole-brain (SPM8 preprocessing, normalization, smoothing, random-effects group analysis with cluster-level FWE correction) and reported whole-brain activation clusters (right ventral striatum, precuneus), not restricted to ROIs. The sample did not include psychiatric or neurological patient groups and is not a review/meta-analysis. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is a task-based fMRI study (Taylor Aggression Paradigm) assessing social interaction/retaliation in healthy adult participants (N=15; mean age 22.3). Whole-brain random-effects analyses and parametric modulation results are reported with Talairach coordinates and cluster correction. No ROI-only analyses, no clinical or psychiatric samples, and it is an original empirical study rather than a review. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an original dual-fMRI (hyperscanning) study in healthy adult participants (mean age 22.4), who performed an interactive social task (pattern game) inside the scanner. Analyses are whole-brain (GLM, group-level random-effects with non-parametric permutation correction) and report cluster-level results across multiple brain regions. No ROI-only analyses, no clinical or disordered sample, and not a review/meta-analysis. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria: fMRI during a social-related task, healthy adults within 18–60, and whole-brain results.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=18, ages 18–41) who watched and understood social communicative interactions (Naming vs. Requesting), i.e., a social-related task. Whole-brain random-effects analyses are reported (FDR-corrected results), alongside ROI/SVC follow-ups, so whole-brain results are available (not ROI-only). Participants are healthy and within the 18–60 age range. The paper is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review, and does not report clinical populations. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (n=16–18 analyzed; ages 21–46) performing social-related tasks (explicit and implicit emotion attribution to human and non-human faces) during whole-brain EPI acquisition. The methods report whole-brain random-effects analyses with cluster-level FWE correction and conjunctions, and results include whole-brain maps alongside ROI analyses. Participants were screened as neurologically and psychiatrically healthy. Age range and health status meet the 18–60 healthy adult criterion. The study is original empirical fMRI research (not a review) and does not report data from clinical populations. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This study employed fMRI while healthy adult participants (female, mean age 21) performed a social task (one-shot Prisoner’s Dilemma), satisfying the social-related task criterion. Participants were healthy university volunteers (age within 18–60). The manuscript reports whole-brain analyses (contrast CC vs. other outcomes, context effects) with cluster-level FWE correction, in addition to ROI analyses; because whole-brain results are present, the study meets the whole-brain inclusion requirement. It is not a review/meta-analysis and does not involve psychiatric/neurological patient samples. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it reports task-based whole-brain fMRI during a social-related task (perception of vocal emotional speech, a form of social/emotional processing). Participants were healthy adults aged 20–35 (N=36), which falls within the 18–60 range. Analyses are whole-brain: data were parcellated using the Power-264 atlas and graph-theoretical metrics and whole-brain functional connectivity (PC and covariance) are reported; results are not limited to region-of-interest only. The paper is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis) and does not involve psychiatric or neurological patient groups. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study that explicitly investigates person/social conceptual processing (fact-learning about people vs. buildings/hammers). Participants are healthy adults aged 20–32 (within 18–60). Imaging used whole-brain EPI coverage and whole-brain random-effects analyses and conjunctions; results and functional connectivity maps are reported across the brain (not ROI-only). The study is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review) and does not involve clinical or psychiatric populations. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This fMRI study used healthy adult participants (N=37, age range 18–25) performing an imitation task involving viewing and imitating others’ hand actions—an experimentally controlled paradigm addressing social-related processing (imitation/urge to imitate). Imaging used whole-brain analyses (first- and second-level random-effects SPM8 analyses, parametric modulation, PPI) with cluster-corrected thresholds; results are not limited to ROI analyses. Participants were healthy with no psychiatric/neurological disorders. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met (task-based fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults, whole-brain results) and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This study reports whole-brain BOLD fMRI during a social interaction (SI) recognition task (point‑light displays) and includes a distinct adult group (mean age 28.8 ± 7.4), which falls within the 18–60 range. Participants were healthy with no neurological/psychiatric disorders. Whole‑brain analyses and adult-group results (SI > NM contrasts and group comparisons) are reported (SPM8, cluster/FWE thresholds), not ROI‑only. Although the sample also includes children/adolescents, adult-specific whole‑brain results are presented and can be extracted for an adult-focused meta-analysis. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for healthy adult whole‑brain fMRI studies of social processing.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (participants aged 18–34 and 18–30 across experiments), using viewing of social interactions as the experimental manipulation with an orthogonal attention task. The paper reports whole-brain group analyses (interaction > independent actions contrasts with FDR correction) in addition to ROI analyses. Participants were healthy and within the 18–60 range. The paper is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis) and does not involve clinical populations. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This study reports an fMRI experiment (Experiment 2) in which healthy adult participants (N=17, mean age 22, range within 18–60) performed social cognition (mentalising/theory-of-mind) tasks while scanned. The task is explicitly social (mentalising vs factual control). Imaging used whole-brain acquisition and analysis with SPM2, reporting whole-brain-corrected results and parametric whole-brain contrasts (no reliance on ROI-only results). Participants were healthy volunteers, and the paper is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review or meta-analysis). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social processing: participants completed a social-related task (knowledge of a friend simultaneously viewing the same emotional pictures — shared vs unshared conditions), which probes social sharing/related processing. Participants were healthy adults (female, aged 20–33). The study reports whole-brain analyses (whole-brain corrected results and cluster-level correction in addition to ROI analyses) rather than ROI-only results. It is an original empirical fMRI report (not a review) and does not involve psychiatric/neurological patient samples. All inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is a task-based fMRI study that examines action observation (watching another person exert force) and action execution, addressing social-related processing (understanding others’ actions/effort). Participants were healthy adults (final N=12; mean age 26±3.5), within the 18–60 inclusion age range. The study reports whole-brain voxel-wise analyses (SPM12 whole-brain GLM) and cerebellum-focused SUIT analyses, with cluster-level correction — not restricted to ROI-only results. It is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis) and does not involve psychiatric or neurological patient groups. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Study used fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=18, ages 18–27) and included an explicit social cognition (mentalizing/Theory-of-Mind) localizer task (false belief > false photograph) performed in the scanner. Whole-brain group analyses were conducted and reported (cluster-corrected p<0.05), in addition to ROI analyses, so results are not limited to ROIs. Participants were healthy with no psychiatric/neurological disorders. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria: fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults with whole-brain results.

Meets all inclusion criteria: Participants were healthy adult humans (male, ages 23–28). The task is socially related (ultimatum game) performed during fMRI acquisition with real-time and offline analyses. The paper reports whole-brain analyses and results (offline whole-brain SVM classification, discriminating volumes and listed informative brain areas across the whole brain), not only ROI findings. No psychiatric or neurological patient groups are included. Therefore the study addresses social processing in healthy adults using whole-brain fMRI and should be included in the review.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it reports a task-based functional MRI study of social-related processing (empathy/social cognition while viewing human and animal suffering), enrolled healthy adult participants aged 18–60 (n=60, range 18–60), and presents whole-brain analyses (SPM2 whole-brain random-effects, FWE-corrected results and interaction analyses). It does not rely solely on ROI analyses, is not a review, and excludes clinical/psychiatric populations. Therefore it should be included in the review of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it used functional MRI during an action-observation task probing social/emotion-related processing (observation of risk-taking vs. safe actions), enrolled healthy participants aged 18–22 (within 18–60), and reports whole-brain SPM analyses (risk-taking vs. safe, conjunctions, and mediation) rather than ROI-only results. No psychiatric/neurological disorders were included. Therefore it is eligible for the review of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is a two-person fMRI study of joint action with direct haptic contact (leading, following, mutual), which is a social-related task. Participants were healthy adult dancers (N=18 after exclusion; mean age 40.4 ±13.2) with no history of neurological or psychiatric disease. The study reports whole-brain analyses (Talairach normalization, voxel-wise contrasts, FDR correction) with coordinates and cluster thresholds. It is not a review/meta-analysis, does not report only ROI results, and does not involve clinical populations. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This fMRI study involved a social-related task (explicit laughter-type categorization assessing socio-relational information, plus an implicit bout-counting task), meeting the requirement of scanning humans during social processing. Participants were healthy adults (N=18, mean age 26 ±3.4 years), within the 18–60 range and free of neurological/psychiatric illness. The paper reports whole-brain analyses (second-level random-effects, whole-brain FWE cluster correction) and whole-brain PPI connectivity analyses; although ROI analyses were also performed, the study is not ROI-only. It is not a review/meta-analysis and does not involve clinical populations. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Although this is an fMRI study of healthy adult physicians (ages 25–37) performing a social task (patient–physician interaction), the neuroimaging results are reported using an a priori region-of-interest (ROI) approach (5 mm spheres around empathy/compassion coordinates) with FWE correction performed within those ROIs. The review’s inclusion criteria require whole-brain results; the study does not report unbiased whole-brain analyses but focuses on ROI results. Therefore it fails the ‘whole-brain results’ inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

While the study meets several inclusion criteria (healthy adult participants aged 22–45; an fMRI task probing social-related processing — passive viewing of own vs. unfamiliar child and dog faces), the reported analyses relied on an a priori ROI approach with small volume correction (SVC) and significance assessed within predefined ROIs. The manuscript does not present whole-brain corrected results across the entire brain volume; findings and statistical inference are constrained to ROI-based SVC and planned contrasts. The review exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting only ROI analyses. Therefore the study must be excluded despite otherwise meeting participant- and task-related criteria.

This study used whole‑brain functional MRI (dual‑fMRI hyperscanning) while healthy adult participants (38 individuals; mean age 22.4, within 18–60) completed an interactive social task (cooperative, competitive, and control rounds of the Pattern Game). Analyses were whole‑brain and data‑driven (group ICA and inter‑subject correlation); results reported spatio‑temporal whole‑brain components and comparisons across conditions (not ROI‑restricted). Participants were healthy and not a clinical sample. The paper is original empirical research (not a review/meta‑analysis). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (fMRI during social task, healthy adults 18–60, whole‑brain results) and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an original fMRI study in healthy adults (n=14, mean age 29.4) that used a social-related task (categorizing point-light displays as social interaction vs non-social) during whole-brain fMRI acquisition. The authors report whole-brain random-effects analyses (FDR-corrected, clusters >10 voxels) comparing SI vs NSI; no ROI-only analyses are reported, no clinical populations are included, and the paper is not a review/meta-analysis. All inclusion criteria are met and none of the exclusion criteria are violated.

Study reports whole-brain fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=23, ages 19–32) during a task involving reading a literary narrative and rating suspense. The neural effects of interest are explicitly social-cognition-related (activations in medial frontal cortex, temporo-parietal junction, theory-of-mind/mentalizing regions) and predictive inference during narrative processing, meeting the review objective of social-related processing. Imaging methods used whole-brain GLM analyses with cluster-level FWE correction and a separate (non-primary) ROI check for the amygdala; main results are whole-brain. Participants were healthy and within the 18–60 age range. The study is not a review/meta-analysis and does not report clinical populations or ROI-only results. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Functional MRI was acquired while participants performed a social task (real-time mutual eye contact vs delayed REPLAY), directly addressing social processing; (2) Participants were healthy adults (N=32–34 analytic sample, mean age ~21.7–21.8), within the 18–60 range; (3) Analyses report whole-brain results (voxel-wise GLM with cluster-level FWE correction, whole-brain gPPI and voxel-to-voxel interbrain synchronization analyses) rather than ROI-only findings. Exclusion criteria not violated: not an ROI-only study, not a review/meta-analysis, and participants were healthy with no psychiatric/neurologic disorders. Therefore the study is appropriate for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This study reports fMRI during a social-related task (viewing empathy-inducing traffic-awareness videos) in healthy adult participants (20 males, age range 20–28, within 18–60). Whole-brain analyses were conducted (CV>NV contrast reported with p<0.05 FWE correction) and results are presented at the whole-brain level; ROI analyses were supplementary and do not dominate the findings. Participants have no reported psychiatric/neurological disorders. The study is not a review/meta-analysis. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (fMRI social task, healthy adults 18–60, whole-brain results) and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is a task-based fMRI study in healthy adult volunteers (n≈50; mean age ~31, within 18–60) that administered the Ultimatum Game — a social/economic exchange task — during scanning. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise analyses (SPM8 ANOVA, whole-brain contrasts with FDR correction and cluster thresholds) and presents whole-brain activation coordinates and statistics. Participants were screened to exclude psychiatric/neurological disorders and prior meditation experience; the sample is not clinical. Although ROI analyses are reported as supplementary, whole-brain results are primary and clearly presented. The study is an original empirical fMRI investigation (not a review/meta-analysis) of social processing in healthy adults and therefore meets all inclusion criteria.

This is a whole-brain event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=12, mean age 25.2) who performed a social-related task (rating intentionality/agency of animated stimuli). The methods report whole-brain acquisition and SPM2-based whole-brain analyses with reported contrasts (high vs low intentionality) and activation maps across brain regions (STS, IFG, occipital areas, etc.). No ROI-only analyses, no clinical or disorder sample, and it is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review). All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Study is an original fMRI experiment with healthy adult participants (N=30, mean age 26) who completed a social-related body perception/self-other distinction task during whole-brain fMRI acquisition. Analyses used whole-brain mixed-effects (FLAME) reporting cluster-corrected whole-brain results; not ROI-only. Participants were screened as healthy and within the 18–60 age range. The work is not a review/meta-analysis and does not include psychiatric or neurological patient groups. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Although this is an fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adult participants (ages within 18–60) using mentalizing/theory-of-mind tasks, the primary analyses and reported results are ROI-based (individually defined ToM ROIs and language ROIs) using within-ROI MVPA. The paper does not present whole-brain voxel-wise results as primary outcomes; instead it focuses on classification within predefined ROIs. The review’s inclusion criteria require whole-brain results and exclude studies reporting ROI-only analyses. Because the study’s reported findings are ROI-restricted, it fails the ‘whole-brain results’ inclusion criterion and meets the exclusion criterion for ROI analyses.

This is an fMRI study of self-referential (social) processing in healthy adults (N=18, ages 19–29). The experiment involved functional MRI during social-related tasks (agentic and conceptual self/other recollection). Whole-brain analyses are reported (whole-brain FWE-corrected results outside mPFC are presented), though an mPFC ROI/SVC was also used; the presence of whole-brain results meets the inclusion requirement. Participants are healthy and within the 18–60 age range. The paper is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis) and does not involve clinical populations. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task involved fMRI during a social-related task (attentional orienting using social gaze vs arrow cues and social voice vs tone contextual processing). (2) Participants were healthy adults (N=22; mean age 22.95 years, all right-handed; within 18–60). (3) Whole-brain analyses were conducted and reported (voxel-wise thresholds with FWE correction), with additional small-volume corrections; results are not limited to ROI-only analyses. Does not violate exclusion criteria: not a review/meta-analysis and participants are not clinical. Therefore the study should be included.

Study includes an fMRI altruism task (dictator-game style) probing social decision-making (focus on partner/ethics), meeting the requirement of scanning humans during a social-related task. Participants are healthy adults (N=55 for altruism; mean age ~28, range within 18–60). Analyses report whole-brain results (searchlight MVPA, whole-brain group-level maps with FWE cluster correction, conjunctions), not limited to ROI-only findings (though some post-hoc ROI tests are reported). The paper is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis) and does not involve psychiatric or neurological patient groups. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (final N=23, mean age 26.4, right-handed, native speakers) that investigated social perception/animacy processing while participants viewed agents interacting with objects — a social-related task. Data were acquired with whole-brain fMRI and analyses were conducted at the whole-brain level (voxel-wise thresholds reported, cluster-level FWE/FDR corrections noted); results are not limited to ROI-only analyses. The study is not a review/meta-analysis and does not include clinical/psychiatric populations. All inclusion criteria are met (task-based fMRI during social processing, healthy participants age 18–60, whole-brain results). No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study should be included.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=30, age range 19–41) performing a social task (responses to gaze shifts of virtual characters). Data were acquired with whole-brain BOLD fMRI and analyses report whole-brain activation results (cluster-forming threshold P<0.001 uncorrected, cluster FWE P<0.05) for main effects and interactions. Although a seed-based gPPI was conducted, the study also presents voxelwise, whole-brain results (and reports FWE-corrected PPI voxels), not limited to ROI-only analyses. Participants were healthy with no psychiatric/neurological disorders. The paper is an original empirical study (not a review/meta-analysis). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Confidence 0.70 below threshold 0.8. This study reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (women aged 18–35) who performed a self-referential, socially relevant task (rating whether they would like to smell like presented body-odour stimuli, i.e., self versus non-self peptide cues). The sample is within the 18–60 range and participants were healthy. The methods state that both whole-brain analysis and small-volume (ROI) analyses were performed; reported effects highlight right middle frontal activation for ‘self’-peptides but whole-brain processing was conducted. The task probes social/self-related processing relevant to the review objective. No psychiatric/neurological patient group was studied. Although the paper emphasizes ROI/SV analyses, whole-brain analyses were performed and participants were healthy adults engaged in a social-related fMRI task, meeting the inclusion criteria.

The study includes social-related tasks (theory-of-mind belief attribution and a social attribution-of-attention task) performed by healthy adult participants (mean ages ~19–23; no psychiatric/neurological disorders) within the 18–60 range. Data were acquired with whole-brain fMRI and analyses include whole-brain seed-to-voxel functional connectivity mapping (CONN toolbox) reporting network-level results beyond the TPJ. Although a localized ICA was applied within a TPJ mask to identify components, the study did not report only ROI-restricted outcomes — it presents whole-brain connectivity and network findings and task-related activation patterns relevant to social processing. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (social fMRI task, healthy adults 18–60, whole-brain results) and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This study reports whole-brain fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=30, females aged 19–39) during social-related tasks: (1) movie viewing of a moral dilemma involving kinship (inter-subject correlation whole-brain analysis) and (2) a moral-decision task (GLM whole-brain analysis). Imaging acquisition and preprocessing covered whole-brain EPI; results are presented as whole-brain ISC and GLM maps with cluster tables. Participants were healthy adults within the 18–60 range. The paper is empirical (not a review) and does not restrict findings to ROI-only analyses. No psychiatric/neurological patient groups were included. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing: participants performed a social touch task (anticipation and performance of touching an animate human vs an inanimate mannequin). Participants were healthy adults (all right-handed males, age 21–33), within the 18–60 range and screened for neurological/psychiatric history. The paper reports whole-brain voxelwise analyses (paired-sample t-tests and covariate analyses with PNI) with FDR correction, and conjunction/whole-brain results are presented; although ROI analyses are included as secondary/exploratory work, the study does not rely solely on ROI results. It is not a review/meta-analysis and does not involve clinical populations. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing: observers judged facing-toward vs away biological motion (PLD and human-like walkers), directly probing mirror-neuron and mentalizing systems. Participants were healthy adults (N=16, mean age 22.75), screened for neurological/psychiatric history, within the 18–60 age range. The paper reports whole-brain contrasts and stereotaxic BOLD peak coordinates; although masked ROIs for MNS/MS were used for focused inference, analyses were performed at the whole-brain second level and results were FWE-corrected (not an ROI-only report). It is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review) and does not involve clinical populations. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

Although this is an fMRI study of social evaluation in healthy adult participants (n=36, mean age 22) using an on-task functional MRI paradigm, the reported neural results were analyzed and reported using a small-volume ROI approach confined to bilateral posterior vACC (ROI-derived, small-volume corrected results). The manuscript does not present whole-brain group results but focuses on ROI-corrected findings; the review’s exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting ROI-only analyses. Therefore the study must be excluded despite meeting other inclusion criteria (healthy adults, social task, fMRI).

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult humans (male participants aged 18–40, final n=67) performing a social task (empathy-for-pain paradigm). The paper reports whole-brain analyses (voxel-level FWE correction) and conjunction/whole-brain results in addition to ROI work, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain results. Participants are healthy (no psychiatric/neurological disorders). The imaging task is social cognition related (empathy/prosocial behavior). No exclusion criteria are violated (not a review/meta-analysis; clinical populations not used; not ROI-only results). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This study reports BOLD fMRI data collected while healthy adult participants (N=20; ages 18–29) performed a social judgment task (forced-choice evaluations of target persons in situational contexts). Analyses include whole-brain multilevel modeling and whole-brain results (clusters reported, voxel coordinates, thresholding), with ROI analyses presented additionally but not exclusively. Participants are healthy and within the 18–60 age range. The paper is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis) and does not report clinical/neurological populations. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (fMRI during social task, healthy adults 18–60, whole-brain results) and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Although this is an fMRI study of social processing (dynamic facial expressions) in healthy adult participants (ages ~22) and uses a social-related task (passive viewing of emotion onsets/offsets), the reported inferential statistics are performed using ROI-based small-volume correction and ROI analyses. The manuscript does not present whole-brain voxelwise results (analyses are constrained to predefined ROIs/SVC), and key findings are reported from ROI/SVC analyses. The review’s exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting only ROI results. Therefore the study must be excluded.

Study used fMRI while participants performed a social-cognitive task (neutral face processing, emotion recognition, affective ToM). Sample comprised healthy, screened adult participants with no history of mental/neurological disorder (consented, ethics-approved). Whole-brain analyses were conducted and reported (FWE-corrected results for task effects and group comparisons), not ROI-only. Exclusion criteria (psychiatric/neurological samples, reviews, ROI-only reporting) are not met. Age range not explicitly reported but participants were adult undergraduates/healthy adults and ethically consented; this creates minor uncertainty reflected in confidence <1.0. Overall meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults with whole-brain results.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (15 right-handed male participants, mean age 23.6) that used a social-related task (observing realistic two-person violent interactions) during whole-brain functional MRI acquisition. Analyses were conducted at whole-brain level (GLM, cluster-size correction, Talairach space) with reported whole-brain contrasts (focus on aggressor vs victim) and connectivity maps; results are not limited to ROI-only analyses. Participants were healthy (no psychiatric/neurological disorders reported). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met (fMRI during social task; healthy adults 18–60; whole-brain results). Note: final N=14 after exclusion and sample is all-male, but this does not violate inclusion/exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (final sample n=34, age 20–30) who performed a social cognition task (modified Empathic Accuracy Task) while scanned. The task assesses empathic accuracy and continuous ratings of others' emotional intensity, clearly addressing social-related processing. Analyses used whole-brain approaches (SPM12 preprocessing, group-level nonparametric permutation testing with TFCE via FSL 'randomise'); reported results are whole-brain clusters with FWE correction. Participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders were excluded. The paper is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis) and does not report ROI-only results. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (theory-of-mind: cooperation, deception) performed in healthy adult participants (n=13; ages 22–38, within 18–60). The task is social-related (attribution of intentions/beliefs), and BOLD whole-brain data were acquired (complete cortical coverage) and an exploratory whole-brain analysis (ToM vs non-ToM) is reported. Although subsequent hypothesis-driven analyses used ROIs derived from the whole-brain results, the study presents whole-brain activation patterns and reports contrasts across ToM conditions. Participants were healthy with no psychiatric/neurological disorders. This is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review) and not limited to patient samples. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (social task, healthy adults 18–60, whole-brain results) and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: study uses functional MRI during a social-related task (imitate/observe emotional faces), participants are healthy adults aged 18–55 (screened with SCID; final imaging sample N=20), and analyses report whole-brain results (spatio-temporal PLS producing voxel maps and a GLM whole-brain analysis in SPM8). It is not an ROI-only analysis, not a review/meta-analysis, and does not report clinical/psychiatric participant results. Therefore it fits the meta-analysis objective of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This study used whole-brain BOLD fMRI while healthy adult participants (mean age 22, screened for neurological/psychiatric illness) performed an implicit social-related task (viewing eyes with dynamic pupillary biofeedback). The design probes social processing (monitoring another’s pupil changes), reports whole-brain group analyses (with corrected thresholds) alongside ROI checks, and participants fall within the 18–60 healthy adult range. It is an original fMRI study (not a review) and does not focus on clinical populations. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an original fMRI study in healthy adults (N=22, mean age 27.35, within 18–60) performing a social-related task (classification of communicative intentions from prosody). Analyses were whole-brain random-effects GLM contrasts (CLEAR > AMBIGUOUS and reverse) with conservative voxel- and cluster-level FWE correction; whole-brain PPI connectivity analyses are also reported. The sample excludes clinical/psychiatric populations and the paper is not a review/meta-analysis. Although amygdala VOIs were used to extract time courses for PPI, results are reported at the whole-brain level rather than ROI-only. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

The study collected BOLD fMRI while participants performed an impression-formation task (social processing of faces varying in race and socioeconomic status), meeting the social-related task requirement. The sample comprised healthy adult participants (final N=60 males, mean age 23.8 years), within the 18–60 range and with no indication of psychiatric/neurological patient samples. Analyses reported whole-brain multivariate (behavioral PLS) results with voxelwise bootstrap-ratio thresholds and cluster reporting (i.e., whole-brain results rather than ROI-only analyses). The study is an original fMRI investigation (not a review/meta-analysis). Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=27; ages ~24–26, right-handed) that used whole-brain functional MRI to examine neural processing of social interactions (cooperative vs affective) while participants viewed realistic human interaction pictures. The task involved passive observation with a secondary target-detection task (landscape detection) and is clearly social-related processing. The paper reports whole-brain random-effects analyses with FWE-corrected thresholds and conjunction/contrast maps; although ROI analyses were also performed, whole-brain results are present. Participants were healthy with no psychiatric/neurological disorders. Not a review/meta-analysis. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (responses to another person controlling subjects’ choices) with a task that manipulates social control; participants were healthy adults (n=51 after exclusions, mean age 22, right-handed, no reported psychiatric/neurological disorders), and data were acquired with whole-brain EPI and analyzed with whole-brain random-effects analyses (cluster-level FWE correction reported). Results are reported at whole-brain level (no ROI-only reporting). The study is original empirical research (not a review) and does not involve clinical populations. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This study reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (N=18; ages 18–30) performing a social task (viewing and classifying faces with gaze/head manipulations). Whole-brain second-level analyses were conducted (reported at p<0.05 FDR whole-brain with cluster threshold) showing AQ-related activation across the social attention network. Participants were typical (no neurological/psychiatric disorders) and within the 18–60 age range. Although supplementary ROI analyses were performed, the primary reported results are whole-brain, not ROI-only. The paper is an original fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis) and does not report clinical samples. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it used functional MRI while participants (healthy, right-handed nulliparous women aged 19–29) completed social-related tasks (viewing and listening to emotional infant faces and cries), so the task involves social/emotional processing. Participants were healthy adults within the 18–60 range and had no psychiatric or neurological disorders. Analyses report whole-brain results with family-wise error correction and whole-brain correlations (not ROI-only). The study is not a review/meta-analysis and does not include clinical populations. Therefore it is eligible for inclusion in the review of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Although this paper reports fMRI of socially relevant processing in healthy control participants (semantic judgments about famous people and social concept words) and presents whole-brain analyses, the provided full-text excerpt does not report participant age ranges or mean ages. The review requires healthy adults aged 18–60; because age inclusion cannot be verified from the supplied information, the study cannot be confirmed to meet ALL inclusion criteria. Therefore it is excluded. If age information from the full paper (e.g., Methods/Participants) is available and falls within 18–60, re-evaluation is recommended.
